choices.text: Mass is mobile only in plane perpendicular to mesentry

questions.text: What is tillaux sign in mesenteric cyst?
questions.solution:
Cysts may occur in any region of the mesentery. They are most often observed in mesentery adjoining the small intestine (60%) or the colon (40%)

Cysts occur most commonly in adults with a mean age of 45 years

  • Twice as common in women as in men
  • Rare: incidence around 1 per 140 000
  • Approximately a third of cases occur in children younger than 15 years
  • The mean age of children affected is 5 years
  • The most common presentation is of a painless fluctuant abdominal swelling near the umbilicus
  • Other presentations are with recurrent attacks of abdominal pain with or without vomiting (pain resulting from recurring temporary impaction of a food bolus in a segment of bowel narrowed by the cyst or possibly from torsion of the mesentery) and acute abdominal catastrophe due to:
    1. torsion of that portion of the mesentery containing the cyst
    2. rupture of the cyst, often as a result of a comparatively trivial accident
    3. haemorrhage into the cyst
    4. infection

Tillaux triad of mesenteric cyst

  • Midline abdominal cystic swelling
  • Mobile cystic swelling at the root of the mesentry perpendicular to it - TILLAUX SIGN
  • Band of bowel resonance around it

questions.text: A 25 year female patient presents with progressive dysphagia to solids and liquids. Barium swallow was done. What are the investigation needed to confirm your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Clinical features such as dysphagia(to both solid and liquid), regurgitation and heartburn are suggestive of achalasia cardia, milder form of which can be often confused with GERD.

The barium swallow shows typical "bird beak sign" Or "rat tail appearance".

Endoscopy typically shows frothy saliva pooling in the oesophagus and the presence of food residue.

Endoscopy must also be performed in all suspected cases of Achalasia to rule out narrowing due to pseudoachalasia (GEJ tumors, stricture, neuropathy)

Definitive diagnosis relies on HRM(high resolution manometry).

questions.text:
Which of the following are components of qSOFA scoring?
1. Respiratory rate
2. Blood pressure
3. CNS features
4. Leukocyte count
questions.solution: SOFA score can be cumbersome to calculate at bedside and requires laboratory test results, a simpler version was developed. The qSOFA can be calculated at a patient bedside by identifying tachypnea, altered mental status, and hypotension. If the patient meets two of these criteria and they are at risk for sepsis, further workup for an infectious source should be conducted.

questions.text: Name this position of the patient in operation theatre?
questions.solution:
Reverse trendelenburg position: the head end of the table is tilted up, thereby placing the head higher than the feet, it is applied in head and neck surgeries including thyroid operation, as the head end is up the veins will collapse and there is less bleeding at surgery.

Trendelenburg position: the head end of the table is tilted down on an incline with the patient's knees slightly flexed, it is applied in varicose vein operation to collapse the lower limb veins while doing surgery by head down leg up position

Lithotomy and Lloyd-Davies position:

This is commonly employed for gynaecological, perineal and urological procedures. The patient is positioned supine with the legs flexed at the hip and knee and placed in stirrups. In the lithotomy position the hips are flexed to 90°; however, the degree of hip and knee flexion can be controlled depending upon the type of procedure performed. The Lloyd-Davies position is a modification of the lithotomy position with hips minimally flexed to around 15° with a 30° head-down tilt.

The jackknife position provides visibility of the anorectal area, so it is commonly used during proctologic procedures, including anorectal and colorectal surgeries (e.g., abdominoperineal resection, when parts of the colon, rectum, and anal sphincter are removed

questions.text:
In the following conditions sanitizer can be used
1. Before examining the patient
2. After examining the patient
3. After touching patient's surroundings
4. When hands are soiled
questions.solution:
Conditions where sanitizer to be used:

  • Before examining the patient
  • After examining the patient
  • After touching patient's surroundings

Soiled hands need to be washed with soap and water, as only sanitiser would not suffice

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS
Wide bore needle insertion followed by intercostals drain in the 5th ICS

questions.text: A 25 year old male patient came to ER with history of trauma, his RR is 35/min and BP is 100/60 mmHg. on percussion hyper resonance is heard over entire right side of the chest. FAST was performed by the doctor which was normal. After looking at the chest X-ray what is the next step in management of this patient
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of history of trauma, unstable vitals, hyper resonance on percussion, points towards tension pneumothorax

  • A tension pneumothorax develops when a 'one-way valve' air leak occurs either from the lung or through the chest wall.
  • Air is sucked into the thoracic cavity without any means of escape, completely collapsing and then compressing the afected lung.
  • The mediastinum is displaced to the opposite side, decreasing venous return and compressing the opposite lung.
  • Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis and treatment should never be delayed by waiting for radiological confirmation. Always treat it with a high index of suspicion of being present

Management:

Immediate next step: needle decompression

  • In children: 2nd intercostal space mid clavicular line
  • In adults: 5th intercostal space mid axillary line

Definitive management: insertion of ICD drain in the triangle of safety

questions.text:
Which of the following symptoms are seen in the child with the following X-ray?

1. Bilious vomiting
2. Palpable mass
3. Hypochloremia and hypokalemia
4. Metabolic alkalosis
questions.solution:
The X-ray given shows single bubble appearance

INFANTILE HYPERTROPHIC PYLORIC STENOSIS

  • Pyloric stenosis presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting starting between 2 and 6 weeks of age. Its presentation differs from infective causes of vomiting (e.g. meningitis, urinary tract infections [UTIs]) because of postprandial hunger.
  • Once vomiting starts, it's frequency and forcefulness increase daily,
  • The diagnosis is made on a test feed or on abdominal ultrasound showing a thickened and lengthened pylorus. In a test feed, gastric peristalsis is seen passing from left to right across the abdomen, and in a relaxed (feeding) baby, the pyloric 'tumor' is palpable as an 'olive' in the right upper quadrant.
  • Feeds are discontinued, and the stomach is emptied with an 8-10Fr nasogastric tube. Loss of gastric acid causes a hypochloremic, hypokalaemic alkalosis with paradoxical
  • correction may take 24-48 hours; 0.9% NaCl with 0.15% KCl in 5% glucose given at 6-7.5 mL/kg/h provides maintenance and corrects defects in most babies. As the chloride deficit is replaced, the kidneys correct the pH.
  • Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy is performed laparoscopically or through a supraumbilical or right upper quadrant incision. A pyloric serosal incision is made, and the 'tumor' spreads, leaving an intact submucosa from the duodenal fornix to gastric antrum. The incision must extend onto the stomach; short incisions cause an early recurrence.
  • Postoperatively, intravenous fluids are continued until feeds are re-established within 24 hours. Early postoperative vomiting usually swiftly resolves, with GOR being more likely than an incomplete myotomy if it persists.

questions.text: Which of the following are used in management of upper Gl bleeding?
questions.solution:
1. Senngstaken blakemore tube: it has 3 lumens and 2 balloons (gastric and esophageal) - used in management of upper GI bleeding as it provides tamponbade effect when the balloons are inflated.
  2. Modified sengstaken blakemore tube (Minnesota tube): it has 4 lumens and 2 balloons (gastric and esophageal) - used in mangement of upper GI bleed and also used for esophageal aspiration.
  3. Upper GIscopy: used to stop upper GI bleeding by injecting endoscopic sclerosants.
  4. Variceal band ligator: used for ligation of Varices to control upper GI bleeding.

questions.text:
Match the following:
Column A:
1.
2.

4.
Column B:
A. Oral and nasal suction tube
B. Gastric compression in adults
C. Urobag
D. Underwater seal
A girl presents with continuous urinary dribbling and she also has fullness of bladder which she voids, since birth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• An ectopic ureter is one that drains to regions other than the bladder. Ectopic ureters are almost always associated with ureteric duplication and are bilateral in 10%.
  • The femaleto-male ratio is 7:1. In females, the ectopic ureter opens either into the urethra below the sphincter or into the vagina.
  • Such a child would complain of incontinence of urine despite normal voiding.
  • In contrast, the male child is always continent as the ureter opens above the external urethral sphincter.
  • Computed tomo-urography (CTU) or magnetic resonance urography (MRU) is diagnostic.

Weigert-Meyer rule:

  • The ureter that drains the upper moiety is at a more inferior and medial position and is prone to obstruction and dysplasia
  • The ureter that drains the lower moiety is at a more superior and lateral position and is prone to VUR

questions.text:
A 35 year old male patient of peptic ulcer disease came with pain abdomen of 2 days duration and obstipation for 2 days, X-ray erect abdomen was done, what is the next line of management of this patient

1. USG abdomen
2. IV fluids
3. Exploratory laparotomy
4. Keep the patient in observation
questions.solution:
Perforation of duodenal ulcer is the most common cause of this pneumoperitoneum

Treatment of peptic ulcer perforation

  • The initial priorities are resuscitation and analgesia. Analgesia should not be withheld for fear of removing the signs of an intra-abdominal catastrophe. In fact, adequate analgesia makes the clinical signs more obvious. It is important, however, to titrate the analgesic dose.
  • Following resuscitation, the treatment is principally surgical. Laparotomy is performed, usually through an upper midline incision if the diagnosis of perforated peptic ulcer can be made with confidence.
  • Alternatively, laparoscopy may be used. The most important component of the operation is a thorough peritoneal toilet to remove all of the fluid and food debris.
  • <1cm perforation: closed primarily and buttress with vascularised omentum
  • 1-3 cm perforation: Graham's omental patch closure
  • >3cm: pyloric exclusion with Roux En Y limb jejunal serosal patch (if the omental is unhealthy) + gastrojejunostomy performed

questions.text: 40 year old female patient underwent cholecystectomy, post OP she is complaining pain abdomen. What test is performed to identify the bile leak
questions.solution:
• The first step following resuscitation and administration of appropriate antibiotics is to undertake urgent USG.
  • This will demonstrate whether there is intra- or extrahepatic ductal dilatation. The anatomy may need to be defined by MRCP or ERCP. The latter is undertaken when therapeutic manoeuvres are planned, such as the removal of an obstructing stone or the insertion of a stent across a biliary leak.
  • If bile duct injury is suspected - CT scan should be performed which shows Ascites or right upper quadrant collection consistent with bilioma.
  • Immediate PCD (percutaneous drain) placement done to control infection.
  • If a fluid collection is present in the subhepatic space, drainage catheters may be required. These can be inserted under radiological control or, if this expertise is not available, at open operation.
  • Electively ERCP is done to know the site and pattern of injury - for which we have a classification known as Strassberg classification.
  • Small biliary leaks will usually resolve spontaneously, especially if there is no distal obstruction. If the CBD is damaged, the patient should be referred to an appropriate expert for reconstruction.

choices.text: Sub dural and dural trauma can be identified

questions.text: What is the additional benefit of doing E-FAST?
questions.solution:
The FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma) examination looks for the presence of fluid-presumed to be blood in the appropriate clinical setting-visualizing 10 structures or spaces in 4 areas:

  • Pericardial
  • Perihepatic
  • Perisplenic
  • Pelvic

The E-FAST (Extended-FAST) additionally surveys the anterior and lateral pleural spaces (thoracic view) to evaluate for a pneumothorax or pleural effusion, assumed to be a hemothorax in trauma patients.

E-FAST has high sensitivity and specificity (especially in patients with hypotension). It can be done quickly, noninvasively, and without radiation exposure, and may be repeated. Due to these benefits, ultrasonography has essentially replaced diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) in evaluation of trauma patients.

In a patient who is hemodynamically unstable, a positive E-FAST may indicate the need for immediate intervention (eg, tube thoracostomy, pericardial window, diagnostic laparotomy).

In a patient who is hemodynamically stable, the E-FAST can direct further diagnostic testing.

Although E-FAST was designed to expedite care in injured patients, the components have proven to be useful as a point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) for patients who are hypotensive but not injured to identify free fluid as a result of other causes (eg, ruptured ectopic pregnancy, ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm).

questions.text: Most common retroperitoneal tumor?
questions.solution:
• Approximately 15% of soft tissue sarcomas arise within the retroperitoneum.
  • In this location, the most common histologic subtypes are liposarcoma and leiomyosarcoma. Most patients present with a large abdominal mass.
  • Abdominal pain is present in about 50% of the patients.
  • Other symptoms are related to organ compression from the tumor and include early satiety, nausea, vomiting, constipation, weight loss, and lower extremity edema.
  • Symptoms due to nerve compression by the tumor, such as lower extremity paresthesia and paresis, are also reported.
  • IOC - CECT abdomen
  • Liposarcoma is diagnosed by variable fat density. No need of image guided biopsy

questions.text: A 40 yr male a known case of varicose veins, on examination eczema and lipodermatosclerosis was found. It comes under ____ of CEAP classification system
questions.solution:
Classification system

The descriptive CEAP (Clinical-aEtiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology) classification for chronic venous disorders is widely utilized.

For clinical classification:

  • C0: no signs of venous disease.
  • C1: telangiectasia or reticular veins.
  • C2: varicose veins.
  • C3: oedema.
  • C4a: pigmentation or eczema;
  • C4b: lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche;
  • C4c: Corona phlebectatica
  • C5: healed venous ulcer;
  • C6: active venous ulcer.

Clinical class can be further characterized as symptomatic (s), asymptomatic (a) or recurrent following previous successful treatment or healing (r), e.g. C2a, C2s, C6r.

For aetiological classification:

  • Ec: congenital;
  • Ep: primary;
  • Es: secondary (post-thrombotic);
  • En: no venous cause identified.

For anatomical classification:

  • As: superficial veins;
  • Ap: perforator veins;
  • Ad: deep veins;
  • An: no venous location identified.

For pathophysiological classification:

  • Pr: reflux;
  • Po: obstruction;
  • Pr,o: reflux and obstruction;
  • Pn: no venous pathophysiology identifiable.

questions.text:
A 45 year old female patient on examination of her breast a 4.5cm * 3cm size irregular mass is felt in the left upper quadrant of the right breast which is not fixed to the pectoralis major muscle and no skin changes, a 2cm*1.5cm lymph node is also palpated in the right axilla. No mass felt in the opposite breast. What all investigations will you do to this patient?
1. Mammography
2. PET scan
3. Biopsy of the breast mass
4. USG guided biopsy of the enlarged axillary lymph node
questions.solution:
According to the case scenario-staging of breast carcinoma - T2N1 - early breast cancer

Mammography in two planes and ultrasonography are the first line investigations for imaging the breast, it is done for both the breast and also to look for multicnetricity

PET scan is done for locally advanced breast cancer

TRU CUT biopsy of lump is the gold standard investigation as it is a tissue diagnosis

USG guided biopsy of the enlarged axillary lymph node is of no use as, if axillary lymph node are enlarged itself indicates local metastasis, which should be managed by axillary dissection.

questions.text: Bile leak from the aberrant right hepatic duct that is not communicating from the bile duct comes under which type of Strassberg classification?
questions.solution:
Strasberg classification of bile duct injuries:

TYPE A-Bile leak from the cystic duct stump or minor biliary radical in the gallbladder fossa.

TYPE B-An occluded right posterior sectoral duct.

TYPE C-A bile leak from the divided right posterior sectoral duct.

TYPE D-A bile leak from the main bile duct without any major tissue loss.

TYPE E:

  • E1, transected main bile duct with a stricture more than 2 cm from the hilus.
  • E2, transected main bile duct with a stricture less than 2 cm from the hilus.
  • E3, stricture of the hilus with the right and left ducts in communication.
  • E4, stricture of the hilus with separation of the right and left hepatic ducts.
  • E5, stricture involving the right aberrant sectoral duct and the main bile duct

questions.text: A 40 year old female, has a massive enlargement of her left breast over 30 days, it is mobile over the chest wall and local rise of temperature is seen, what is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Inflammatory breast cancer is rare, accounting for approximately 1% to 5% of all breast tumors, it is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer.
  • The hallmark of inflammatory breast cancer is diffuse tumor involvement of the dermal lymphatic channels within the breast and overlying skin, often without a discrete underlying tumor mass. Inflammatory breast cancer manifests clinically as erythema, edema, and warmth of the breast as a result of lymphatic obstruction.
  • There may be no abnormality on mammography beyond skin thickening, and a palpable mass is not required for the diagnosis. The term peau d'orange is used to describe the orange-peel appearance of the skin resulting from edema and dimpling at sites of hair follicles.
  • The history should reveal a rapid onset of the disease, with progression over weeks to 3 months.
  • Inflammatory cancer is a clinical diagnosis and can occur with tumors of ductal or lobular histology.
  • The pathologic hallmark of inflammatory cancer is the presence of tumor cells within dermal lymphatics.
  • Axillary nodal metastases are common, and there is a significant risk for distant metastases.

questions.text: A young male with head injury was brought to the emergency in unconscious state. The patient was not able to breath properly, put on ventilatory support. On examination, GCS was 8 with findings of raised ICT. NCCT brain and spinal imaging were normal. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This is a form of primary brain injury seen in high-energy accidents that usually renders the patient comatose;
  • it is associated with poor outcomes. It is strictly a pathological diagnosis made at postmortem, but haemorrhagic foci in the corpus callosum and dorsolateral rostral brainstem on CT may be suggestive, although CT often appears normal
  • Magnetic resonance imaging is more sensitive and is employed to evaluate for difuse axonal injury in patients who fail to improve neurologically.
  • IOC for diffuse atonal injury is SWI-MRI

questions.text: As per European Hernia Society Classification-Incisional hernia at level of umbilicus is given the term

choices.text: Medial boundary of Triangle of Doom is vas defrens
Lateral boundary of Triangle of Pain is iiliopubic tract
Myopectineal orifice is bounded by internal oblique and transversus abdominis superiorly
Myopectineal orifice bounded by illiopubic tract inferiorly

questions.text: Regarding the boundaries of laparoscopic anatomy of inguinal hernia-false statement is
questions.solution:
Myopectineal orifice of FRUCHAD

  • Medial - Rectus sheath
  • Lateral - illiopsoas
  • Superior - conjoint tendon
  • Inferior - pecten pubis

Triangle of pain boundaries

  • Medially - gonadal vessels
  • Superiorly - illiopubic tract
  • Laterally - peritoneum

Triangle of doom boundaries:

  • Medially: spermatic cord
  • Laterally: gonadal vessels
  • Inferiorly: peritoneal reflection

questions.text: A 10 years old girl presented with growing left sided neck swelling, as given in the image. The swelling was firm and non-tender. She had freckles and flat spots on the face and trunk. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Neurofibromas are benign tumours that arise from the nerve sheath.
  • There are three major types of neurofibroma: cutaneous, spinal and plexiform. In 90% of cases they present as solitary lesions, with the remainder presenting in patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF-1), an autosomal dominant genetically inherited disease. NF-1 occurs in 1 in 3000 births and has been referred to as peripheral neurofibromatosis or von Recklinghausen disease.
  • It arises from gene mutation on chromosome 17
  • Diagnosis of NF-1 is confirmed when an individual has two or more of the following: at least six cafe-au-lait macules >5 mm diameter before puberty or six cafe-au-lait macules >15 mm after puberty, two or more neurofibromas of any type or one plexiform neurofibroma, multiple freckles in the axillary or inguinal regions, a distinctive bone abnormality involving the eye socket or arm/leg bones, optic glioma in the brain, two or more Lisch nodules in the eye, and a parent, sibling or child with NF-1

questions.text: Match the following (nerves injured in surgery):
questions.solution:
• Long thoracic nerve of bell can be injured in modified radical mastectomy results in winging of scapula
  • External laryngeal nerve is the most common nerve injured in thyroidectomy
  • Phrenic nerve is injured in VATS (video assisted thoracic surgery) thymectomy
  • Lingual and hypoglossal nerve is injured in submandibular gland excision.

questions.text: A 40 years old patient, with previous history of MI, presented to the emergency with history of multiple episodes of vomiting, pain abdomen and blood in stool. On examination, BP-90/60 mmHg, PR-112/minute and pulse were irregularly irregular. Abdomen was soft, non-distended and bowel sounds were absent. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario suggest a case of ACUTE MESENTERIC ISCHEMIA

  • Acute mesenteric occlusion may be either thrombotic (following atheromatous narrowing) or embolic.
  • Embolic occlusion results in sudden, severe abdominal pain, with bowel emptying (vomiting and diarrhoea) and a source of emboli present (usually cardiac).
  • Unfortunately, the diagnosis is often only made at laparotomy with widespread infarction of the small and large bowel present; in this situation it is often fatal.
  • Occasionally, the degree of bowel infarction is more limited; resection of the dead bowel and embolectomy of the superior mesenteric artery, or bypass surgery, can reduce the otherwise high mortality rate in these patients.
  • A 'second look' laparotomy 24 hours later to check the viability of the bowel may be indicated

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct related to the image given below?
1. Peripheral neuropathy
2. Distal pulses not palpable
3. Restriction in movement of toes
4. Diabetes mellitus
questions.solution:
This is a picture of TROPHIC ULCER

  • Multiple factors contribute to trophic ulcer like neuropathy + vasculopathy
  • The major causes are - diabetes, leprosy, peripheral vascular disease etc
  • The absence of pain perception and excess pressure results in such type of ulcers.
  • Secondary infection may occur

choices.text: Duplex scan of lower limb vessels

questions.text: 35 year old male, chronic smoker came to OPD with right calf muscle pain and ulcer over the great toe with surrounding black pigmentation. What is the next investigation you do to this patient?
questions.solution:
The history given here is suggestive of buerger's disease

The next investigation is to do DUPLEX scan to know the distal blood flow in lower limbs. This major non-invasive technique uses B-mode ultrasound to provide an image of vessels

IOC for atherosclerotic diseases is DIGITAL SUBSTARCTION ANGIOGRAPHY (DSA)

questions.text: A 25 years old female presented with rapid weight gain, loss of appetite. Investigations show increased TSH with low T4. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above history and investigation is suggestive of hypothyroidism, with hashimotos thyroiditis being the most commmon cause of hypothyroidism in females

  • This common condition is usually associated with raised titres of thyroid antibodies.
  • It commonly presents as a goitre, which may be difuse or nodular with a characteristic 'bosselated' feel or with established or subclinical thyroid failure.
  • The diagnosis often follows investigation of a discrete swelling.
  • Features of chronic lymphocytic (focal) thyroiditis are commonly present on histological examination in association with other thyroid disease, notably toxic goitre.
  • Primary myxoedema without detectable thyroid enlargement represents the end stage of the pathological process

questions.text: In a patient, metastasis was found in liver. On biopsy, it was found to be adenocarcinoma. It was cytokeratin-20 positive and cytokeratin-7 negative. Primary is most likely from:
questions.solution:
Colon cance: CK 20+ve, CK 7 -ve

Reference: pathology question

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about Peutz-Jeghers syndrome?
1. Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium is most common extra-intestinal manifestation
2. Arborizing pattern
3. STK11 mutation
4. Autosomal recessive
5. Multiple GI polyps seen
questions.solution:
• This is an autosomal dominant condition characterised by melanosis of the mouth and lips, with multiple hamartomatous (benign tumour-like malformations resulting from faulty development in an organ) polyps in the small bowel and colon.
  • Mutation of the STK11 gene on chromosome 19 has been found in a proportion of patients.
  • Despite the increased risk of malignancy in general, malignant change in the polyps themselves is uncommon. Resection may be indicated, however, for heavy and persistent or recurrent bleeding or intussusception.
  • Polyps may be removed by enterotomy or, at laparotomy, snared via a colonoscope introduced via an enterotomy.
  • The histological hall mark is the presence of smooth muscle fibres in an arborizing pattern.
